sp.p: I will. But is it time? Brother, would you would doe me the fauour to inquire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, ile goe see for the Possets sake.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Captaine, deale fairely with me. By what mean • s ioyned you with this society? or how grew so soone your trust or great acquaintance with them?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Without offence ile tell you. You know this Morning at your Lodging, there past some words betwixt mee, and your sullen Kinsman, Master—indeed la, Tridewell, and from him too much indeed for me, a profest Souldier to beare: But the place protected him. Till after vpon m •
ture consideration I made after him for satisfaction, thus
arm'd as you see. Purposing with this Ropes end to right me; and to maintaine that right with this sword, which I thanke Mars neuer yet faild me; as it hath well beene manifested by the effusion of much vnworthy blood of my abusers, in France, Spaine, Italy, Poland, Sweden, Hungary, all parts of Germany.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good Captaine trauell not so farre in your relation: but come home againe to the businesse.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I haue vs'd it in some score or two of Sea fights too by the way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But to the matter Captaine; where met you my Cosen?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The first sight I recouer'd of him, was as he was entring the house of the greasie Knight there, what call you him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul Squelch?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Squelch, I a pox squelch him. I waited a quarter of an houre at his doore, for your Kinsman; and longer I would not, had he beene Kinsman to the Emperour, and my Enemy. Therefore in I went, told Master Tridewell in his eare, my comming was to call him forth, to dischardge the office of a Gentleman with his Sword, in answering those wrongs wherewith I held my reputation wounded. Was it not well, ha? Could a poore Gentleman say more? and that in ciuill fashion very priuately in respect of the company, not shewing any the least distemper, in looke or gesture. But the Women read presently in his countenance the whole matter; and briefly by their pretty perswasion I tooke ordinary satisfaction of him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was that Captaine?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Why hee confes • 'd hee wrong'd me, was sorry for't, and so forth. What should we speake more on't. This you must not speake of neither. You must promise me that o' your honour, as you desire to heare what followes: I loue no ripping vp old so • res.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not a word I, Captaine vpon my word. What a Rascals this! to the point good Captaine.

sp.speaker: A • .
sp.p:
Then thus sir? I soone perceiu'd, their drist to appease,
& winne me to their friendship was for my assistance, and indeede to beare the • out in this nights worke, the Maske. The whole plot of all which was meerely to so we dissention betweene you and your new married Lady, to worke if they can a seperation, before carnall copulation, in which if they can prevaile, and that the dislike continue betweene you to that height, that a divorce be required equally by the consent of you both, your Marriage then is frustrated, and you stand in stat • quo prim dee heare. So your Cosen Tridewell may lawfully pursue his hopes in your Bride, whō he loues as eagerly as the melancholly virgine dotes on you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But may this hold good in Law Captaine?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There's a Ganon for it Sir. If both parties agree to a divorce after Marriage, so it be before Copulation.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Though the former part of his discourse, was a most egregious lye, yet the last hath some sound of pleasure in it: which I may make vse of.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Come gi'me the instrument. Shall I neuer find thee any where, but thou wilt by iust desert exact a beating from me? Hast thou no conscience? wouldst thou haue me lame my selfe, or melt my grease vpon thee. Come Sir, I haue ouer-heard you all; giue mee the Instrument, the instrument I say. Indeede I'le haue it. So. Now Sir—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay Cosen, for the seruice hee hath done you to night, and loue of mee, pardon him this time. Besides, his charge is in the house, at whose charge he liues. You will both shame and vndoe him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well Sir, I shall for this time pardon you, and neuer beat you more, it before Sir Phillip here you will subscribe to this. Tis nothing but a faithfull protestation to do reasonable things as I shall appoint, and not to reueale what I shall trust you withall.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If you will couenant on your part in defence of my reputation, to let me rayle at you behinde your backe, I will subscribe▪

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Take your pleasure. I am content. Write Sir.
In what without a Knaue we cannot end,
A Knaue imployd do's th' o • fice of a frend.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Here Sir, I deliuer it as my deede.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here, and I deliuer you this againe to keepe. Indeed you shall for performance of couenants.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh Sir you are defeated. My sister hath fortified her lodging with locks, bolts, barres, and barricados.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To what • nd brother: for what cause?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I know not whither it be discontent or wilfulnesse, that possesses her: but you are to haue no entrance there to night. That she has suificiently sworne.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! am I denied? To my wish.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Pray let me speake with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: At large you shall. For though it bee my wedding night you shall be my Bedfellow. Lights there. Good night brother.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good night Captaine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now Goue • nour? what has angerd thee? something troubles thy countenance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Your comming, and the priviledge of this place hath once more preseru'd that vnworthy Tridewell from the justice of my fury, which should haue fallen on him, had he bin tw • nd with me by this light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By this light, Gouernour? would you haue fought by Candl • -light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir I dare do't by day light, Moone-light, Star-light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ow'e-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Any light vnder the S • nne. And that shall bee tride well on Tridewel •
head, dec heare?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A good iest! Tride well vpon Tridewell. He has wit in his anger. But Gouernour, laying your anger aside, let me be behol • en to your wit in atchieuing this Northern Lasse. Thy acquaintance with her must be the meanes. Prithee goe lye with me, and helpe mee to dreame • ut some course. Nay looke now thy furie blowes so high thou dost not heare me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Not h • are? ye • , were I in a Combat as great as euer I my selfe fought any, I could both heare, and giue counsell. Therefore say vnto your selfe, by the helpe of your
Gouernour shee is your owne.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O Man past example!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But dee heare?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here, here. Thou shalt haue anything—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Come your wayes huswife. No more of your whynings, and counterset tricks. If this Gentleman be not worthy of your loue, I am not worthy to be your Vnc • e, directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Alas, what meane you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Accept of him, you accept of me. if you refuse him you deny me directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee vnderstands you not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: If you will ioyne hands and faith with him, Here's your portion, there's your ioincture; if not, your way lies before you, pack directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Good sir, consider her disease. If her vnderstanding were direct, you might speake directly to her. But if I haue any discretion shee is too full of melancholly to be purg'd this way.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What would you haue me doe? Or how in your discretion would you councell me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Not to be mad sir, because shee is melancholly, not by taking a wrong course for her recouery to ruine her, and forfeit your iudgement Doe you thinke, that commands with chidings, threats, or stripes haue power to worke vpon her, when shee has neither will nor reason vvithin her selfe to doe, or not to doe anything whatsoeuer.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now the g • gs vp.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If her health in sense and vnderstanding were perfect: yet as shee is Woman, her will were first to be wrought vpon by faire and gentle treaty. But as shee is at this time so sicke in mind, that knowledge of what shee i • , what shee do • , especially of what shee should doe is dead in her, her Mind must bee first recouer'd; and that by a due course, in soft and temperate proceedings; to which fit time as well as meanes must bee • ilovved. Moreouer—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Oh. No moreouers I besee • h you, not more of her at this time. I vnderstand your purpose already. I doe directly. Therefore speedily take what course, and vse what meanes shall in your discretion be thought fit. I will subcribe, I will directly
〈◊〉 to your discre • ion. My wise when thee went out of the wo • l • le • t me as great a c •• e behind her in the charge she gaue me with this Woman, this quick fighted Guide of my house, a blind one were better.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You should first see, if it pleased you, how her affection may b • e wrought vpon by the Gentlemans owne faire intreaty. Pray sir speake to her like a Su • er, looke vpon him Sweet heart: This Gentleman loues you. Pray speake sir. Doe you not?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: N • uer credit me pretty Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor will I, feare it not. Nor any man that sayes hee loues me. For alas! I was too lately sco • n'd.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p:
You are a L • sse indeed. I pro •• st and vow, and such •
• ne, as I would bee very •• rry to appeare any way, or in the least 〈◊〉 , as it were please you to vnderstand me: for Ile be sworne, • he • e is not in the World.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Truth in swearing, lesse in promising.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If you will beleeue me Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor ne man for your sake.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world I say—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I say so too sir. What wast I pray.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world any Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tell that no further; for wee are all too gentle lessen men were lesse cruell.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Heare him speake Constance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You shall heare me sing first by your leaue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Poore heart.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here's wise worke! direct •• nacy and Ideotismc. Blesse my house from the Ward Masters Informers,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray sir, are you sir Phillip?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Say you are.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Yes Lady, I am sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But you are none of my Sparrow. Your mouth's not wide enough for your words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee has stop'd his mouth there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: His words would soften Adamantine eares. And lookes would melt a Marble hea • t to teares. O Wea is me!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay you must not weepe Swe • t-heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 I doe them? Shall I euer get him by singing trou yee? Introth I would neuer but sing, if I thought that were the gainest way.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I had rather heare you sing though, then see you weep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It must bee of my Loue than, my Sparrow as I told you. And thus it goes.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: A bonny bonny Bird I had
A bird that was my Marroe:
A bird whose pastime made me glad,
And Phillip twas my Sparrow.
A pretty play-fere: Ch •• p it would,
And hop, and fly to fist,

Keep •
• ut, as • were a Vsur • rs Gold,
And bill me when I list.
Phillip, Phillip, Phillip it cryes
But hee is fled and my loy dyes.
But were my Phillip comd a gaine,
I would not change my Loue
For Iuno's bird with gawdy traine,
Nor yet for Venus Doue.
Nay, would my Phillip come againe,
I would not change my state,
For his great Name sakes wealth of Spaine,
To be anothers Mate.
Phillip Phillip, &c.

sp.p: No no, you cannot be the Man. I know him right weel by you sir, as w • ly as you be. Gin you had all his trim geere vpon you, and all his sweets about you, yet I should not bee so fond to mistake a Ienny How let for a Tasse • Gentle. Ah, ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why Lone, what faul • doe you find in this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Feath, but eene eane. That her is not • ir Phillip. For thus would hee doe. Thus would hee kisse his hand; and thus ta' me by mine. Thus would hee looke, and set his eye on mine: And giue mee lea •• to see my selfe in's eye • . Twas the
best Glasse introth that ere I saw. I nere looke weell fine. Nor ere shall ime sure, vntill I see me there againe.
sp.l: But hee is geaue, alas hee's geane, and all too late I sorow.
For I shall neuer bee well againe, till yesterday be to marow.
sp.p: God you good Euen sir.—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: • ollow her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And put her to't sir, and out of this humo • . Ile add the tother fiue hundred to her portion, and you bring her about handsomely. O when I was a Batchelor! I thinke I can doe somewhat yet in my old dayes. But when I was a Batchelor, how I could haue handled this geere.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Neuer credit me sir, if you will beleeue me but—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I doe beleeue you sir sufficien • ly good Master Nonsense. No more of your impertinent speec • es. But follow her, and put her to' • I say, to' • directl • . Take her into the Orchard •
• as there shee fell in loue they say It may bee the place is O neno • .

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, there will bee no way for her recouery, but to rem • u. her lodging, and haue some good Phisicians about her.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Where you please; and vse vvhose helpe you please: sh • e is your ovvne; dispose of her treely, as I vvill of what is
〈…〉 course of life directly. Let me see. Shee
〈◊〉 , past recouery. Say I should marry, I might yet haue an
〈…〉 mine ovvne.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, but of whose getting sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There might rise a fearefull question.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Thinke not of it sir. A man of your yeares, and grauity, vvith the respect the World giues you for your place and vvorship in the Common Wealth, together vvith the riches you haue p • ld vp in a Mountainous estate; to cast all dovvne vvith your 〈◊〉 , and fortune at the foot of a stranger I Thinke vvhat vvould be thought of you, if such a dotage should possesse you

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Shee's falling into a tedious Lecture.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Pray hovv vvas Master Spartledirt talk'd on tother day for doing such a tricke? yet he vvas held a vvise Lavvyer: You see a faire example in the late Mariage of sir Phillip Lucklesse, and his Fitchow, a Match of your ovvne making, and
•• use of your Neeces and your ovv • e Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: There's tugging for a Mastery, and buffetting for the breeches. He barks at her, shee snaps at him; shee breaks his wine Glasse, hee her looking Glasse; shee puts away his Seruants, hee turnes away hers; shee locks her Chamber dore, he bolts his, begetting nothing but a World of strife and disorder.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray shut vp that point, I will not marry. No directly I will not, though the truth is my purpose: was to haue cast my selfe and fortune wholly vpon y • u, if 〈◊〉 might houe seem'd well in your discretion, vmh vmh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I pray stay a little sir, take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not a step further, this way by your leaue. I thinke I haue pusseld • er discretion.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Vnderstand me sir. As I would not haue you fall rashly vpon anything; no more would I haue you flie sodainly from any purpose, without advise and sober deliberation. If you should marry one that would be a Comfortable Nurse vnto you, as (though I say' • ) you partly know—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Say you nothing, • er I doe know nothing, nor I will know nothing more of this matter directly: For if euer I ma • ry, let me suffer a • that the-Law prouides for Periuty; let me bee cropt and slitt worse then a French Curtall, or a parliamentall delinquent for blaspheming the blood royall. No, I wi • now bestow my wealth in Mo • umentall good deedes, and ch • ritable vses in my life time, to bee talkd well on when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, build Almes houses and Hospitals for beggers, and prouide in Bridewell, and houses of Correction for your frends and ki • d • ed. Pray giue enough to Bedlem, you may feele some part of that benefit your selfe before you die, if these sits hold you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Shee would haue me doe no good with that I haue n ••
ther. Let mee consider. The most I haue to say directly 〈◊〉
not beene very well gotten. Were it not a point of good conscience, to spend that prodigally, and saue a 〈…〉
And that which I haue g • t well and honestly, hath beene 〈◊〉
much care and trauell; were it not then a point of equity to my selfe, to spend that with ease and pleasure? Tis done directly, what I haue is mine owne; and I will be merry with it. Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What's the toy now?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirah. Take there twenty peeces. B stow it all presently in choycest meates, and richest Wines for my Supper. This one nights Supper directly. What I haue is mine owne: and I will be merry with it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Cl • . Blesse vs!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Six brace of Partriches, and sixe Pheasants in a Dish. Godvvits, Knots, Quailes, and the rest of the meares ansvverable for halfe a score, or a dosen persons of the best quality: vvhom I vvill thinke of presently.

sp.speaker: Cl • .
sp.p: Braine of a dovvne right Iustice! VVhat meanes my Master, to leape out of thirtie shillings a Weeke house keeping into tvventie pounds a Supper? I may sell my Clearks place: for sure he meanes to thrust himselfe out of the Commission. Hee can be no Iustice long if this humor hold. Who shall be the Guests tro • ?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I h • ue it directly. You shall goe to the Ordinaries, and from thence inuite such young G • llants as you find to be Ga •
•• rs. I meane of the highest cut.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Men that you doe not know sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I directly. If they know me, or haue heard of me tis sufficient: we shall be s • one acquainted. Bring not a man with any paid for gold Lase or Searlet about him, I charge you, nor without a Protection in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You run a great hazard in this sir. You may perhaps be cheated of all you haue, if I haue any discreation.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And much good do't their good hearts. What I haue is mine owne, and I will bee merry with it directly. You haue put me by one or two courses: But not all your discretion shall beat me out of this. If you take some care in the busines, and huswife the intertainement to make it braue for my credit, you may get a Gowne or a Iewell by it. If not—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir ile obey you. If he bee mad I will not bee foolish, bat strike in for a •• are. And for your Guests sir, let me alone. My man is b • st acquainted at the Ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Why now you speake.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Within there. Beauis. But introth sir, I doubt whither any such Guests will come, you haue alwayes beene so strict and terrible in your iustitrary courses.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Let him say mine eyes are opened, and their vertue is reuealed
vnto me. And if any of the youngsters haue Mistrisse • , let' hem bring'hem. They shall haue Mn • cke • what I haue is mine owne, and I will be me •• y with it. My flesh, though not in the way of mariage, requires some satisfaction too. Where might a man in all this plenti • ull Towne, find a choyce peece directly that he might make his owne? only his owne? A very hard question. And custome has made it almost an vnreasonaone, though it were in ones owne Wife. In a Cittizens or Tradesmans Wife; a Man must suffer the Riuall-ship of a slouenly husband: the stinke of his hornes euer vnder ones nose. A cast Lady, or Gentlewoman of courtly acquaintance, to maintaine her, is to • eed a Fountaine, that wasts it selfe through many Spow • s: What I supply her with, will be drawne out by twenty. All her friends must share of my prodigality. To traine vp an innocent countrey Girle, is like hatching a Cuckoe; as soone as shee is ripe, and sees the world afore her, shee flies at her aduantage, and leaues mee dead i'the neast. How now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Delinquent brought before your worship to be examined, a Gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Sq • .
sp.p: Who brings her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ve • hem the Constable sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Looke on his feet. Sure tis the Diuell in his likenesse: That old Bawd knowing how it stood with me, has brought me one of his Succubae Art. Sure tis Vexhem?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sure sir? The diuell himselfe knowes him not better then I know him from the Diuell. I am sure, hee has beene in see with me these nine yeares: almost euer since hee was Constable; and has brought more profit to my deske then all the honest Officers in the counties of your Commission sir. Oh hee's a rare fellow, hee'll tickle a Whore in Coany.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You know my mind. I will in and handle this g • ere in priuity.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Beauis, You vnderstand me. Prithee goe discreetly about it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray let me see a little of this first.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p:
If I put her to't or euer offer to put any Woman to't againe, neuer credit me: let me neuer be trusted, I protest and
〈◊〉 Gentlewoman shee has vs'd me—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Very ill fauouredly me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Ha' you put herto't sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I cannot put her to't, nor she will not be put to't. Sing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I wo'not goe to't, nor I man not goe to't,
For loue, nor yet for see:
For I am a Mayd, and will be a Mayd,

And a good one till •
• aye.
Yet mine intent, I could repent, for • ne mane company.
sp.p: But you are not he Sir. If you b • , you are wondrously chang'd. I am sure his faults were not written on his forehead. God pardon him.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If mine bee, you can best read'hem, t'is your owne hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Shee has done a cure on him. Hee spoke sense now. Alas Sir, that a faire hand should make such blots I what hand i •
it? Secretar, Romane, Court, or Text? I haue not seene the like: 'tis all dominicall letters, red Inke. His face is like an Almanack of all Holy • ayes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sure tis Stenography, every Character a word: and here and there one for a whole sentence.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here's one might serue for a whole History. The life and deatho' Raw head, and Bloody bones.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I see I am not such an Asse, I would I might neuer stir but I am—Wh • r • 's S • r Paull If I doe not tell him—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What did you to prov • ke her thus?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Nothing but what I can ans • ere in a sort dee see me as well as—neuer 〈◊〉 credit I had warrant vnder his hand

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: N •• .
sp.p: By word of mou • h sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: That's about hand by your leaue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Is it so? Good S • r, his meaning was, you should put her fairely on like a Louer, with sweet speeches, and gentle behaviour.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: S • ee vnd •• stands nothing that I can speake.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Nor any body else I thinke.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And therefore you fell to expresse your selfe in rude action. Shee has sorn'd you but well: you are a sine putter to't indeede.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Mum to • t Mun toot, Muntara rara Muntara ra ra rarie,
And euer I sigh and cray alack for Phillips loue I die.

• ust so did our Deyry Mayd at home serue my Lady Fidledees Batler. And there I learnt it. But when shee had so done what did shee than doe? Bestow'd a penyworth of Vnguentum Album, and it made him whole presently. Good Mrs. Traynwell send to your Poth • cary for some: 'twill make him wee •
e'n •• now.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: I sweet-heart: but first you shall goe in the Coach with •• to the Doctors.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: I know I am not weell too. But Ile ha'no Doctor but Sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
It shall be Sir Phillip, (poore soule,) all must be Sir Phillip.
• ou shall lye at his house.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But not wi • h him by my faith, and your leaue, in't wee be married. Prithee Beauis gar him wash his face hee'll scare some bodies Barnes else.—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Ile throw him into the Dock rather then he shall succeede Iack O'Dandy. Come sir, all shal be wel again. Feare not.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

div.head: Act. III. Sce. III.

sp.speaker: Luc.
Tri.
sp.p: Follow but the way you are in Sir, and you shall arriue at your owne wishes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shee has put me into't her selfe too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: By sequestring her selfe from you the first night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For which Cosen, if I take not occasion to keepe my selfe from her, all nights, dayes, and times hereafter, may the act of our bodies beget prodigeous monsters and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A fearefull vow! looke too't. And I warrant shee sues for the Divorce first.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
May wee proue but as certaine as you are confident in out other proiect, for recalling Constance to her selfe, and mee
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
then to her, these • etters being shaken off, may they pro • e g • lden ones to you, I shall not envie you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For her take no thought sir. The intrest I haue in her Tu • resse, with the work I haue fashion'd vpon my Anvil, shall bring all to your wish. I expect to heare from him instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile freely resigne your wish to you, and adde halfe I haue to a • gment her estate to you. Oh I tremble • o thinke on her: her presence shakes the house like an earthquake: the outrage of Prentizes is not so terrible to a Bawd or a Cutpurse, as her voyce is to me. Yet to you shee may be calme as the breath of friendship, and milde as the midnight whispers of chast loue.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir, I professe my affection flies eagerly at her. Shee takes me deepely, how euer you haue mistaken one another. Oh here comes my Anvile! Mee thinkes his very countenance invites me to strike him▪ though I know hee dos me good service now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Tis done sir. I warrant shee's plac'd, succesfully, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I haue sent her before his Worship by a Constable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who has he sent? before whose Worship?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You shall know all. He has sent your cast whore before sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Mistery, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: The successe shall vnfold it in good time to your and my benefit? doubt not, if she but follow her instructions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, if shee be not Mistris of her Art, there is no deceit among Trades men, no bribery among Officers, no bankrupt out of Ludgate, nor Whore out of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And if I ha' not fitted her with a Second, my friend vex h • m, the Constable, then say there is no wit among Kna • es, no want among Schollers, no rest in the graue, nor vnquietnesse in Mariage, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Of which here comes the truest testimony.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out of my doores thou Miscreant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay sister. O governour, art here.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Avoyd my house, and that presently, Ile claw your skin
off after your Liuory else, and make you so much nakeder then time makes all other seruing Creatures.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe you talke of turning away my Man? You shall give me leaue to turne away your Howdee first, and then put off my, God a mercy how dost thou.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I ieerd? flowted to my face? Is this fit vsage for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Lu • .
sp.p: A Wife? a Witch.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A Husband? a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Lu • .
sp.p: Out pusse.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Nay sir, indeed the fault is yours most extreamly now. Pray sir forbeare to straine beyond a Womans patience.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I scornd and reuild?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Made a property for laughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Haue I no friend, no Seruant to command?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Has my Ladiship made me so lamentable a thing, that I haue lost the power of a Mistris? You sir, run and call some frends to succour me, or Ile thratle you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stirre but a foot sirah, or vtter but a sillable, and ile cut your thratle pipe.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I shall be caru'd out betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What will become of me? you, VVood-cock, Ninihammer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Haue you forgot my name sister? would not Widgin •
become your mouth, as wel? forget your natural brothers name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Can you call me sister, and see me abus'd thus?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Foutre for sisters; I am not to medle with an other mans Wife. I am about one for my selfe. You mention'd her first to me. But I must be be holden to others wits and meanes to compasse her: or else—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe as I bid you, or—

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O sir shee'll rend me in peeces, teare me like a Larke.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dost thou feare her or me. Do't or I—

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, there's Master Walt • r can sing it rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he shall sir, and so will all; but you must put vs in. Beginne.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hey downe downe, &c.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: S • ster, VVife, and a • l, is a present nothing to this. Come rou • d Gentlemen▪ Keepe her but off, and let me alone.

div.p: They all take hands, and dance round. VVidgine in the midst sings this Song. They all b • are the burden, while she • scold • and striues to be amongst'hem. T ••• ewell holds 〈◊〉 off.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Hee that marries a Scold, a S • old,
Hee has most cause to be m • rry:
For when shee's • n her fits, he may cherish his wits
By singing hey downe derry.

sp.speaker: A • l.
sp.p: —Hey downe downe derry downe downe downe, &c.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Gallants. I apprehend you would bee priuate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O 〈◊〉 M • ster Bulfinch, you shall make one of our Counc • ll.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I appreh • n • Gen • lemen you are merrily dispos'd; in good • adnesse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: App • e • end a • o • les head. Come into play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I, 〈◊〉 with him, and about againe.

div.stage: They pull him into the Round.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that marries a merry Lasse,
For let her goe free in her merry tricks, shee
Will worke his Patience mad.
But he that marries a 〈◊〉 a Scold, &c.
He that weds with a Roa • ing 〈◊〉 ,

that will both • crat •• and 〈◊〉
▪
Though he study all day to make her away,
will be glad to please her at night.
And he that copes with a sullen Wench,
That • carc • will speake at • ll,
Her doggednesse more then a Scold or a Whore,
Will perpetr • te his Gall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hey downe downe, &c.
He that's matchd with a Turtle Do • e,
That has no spleene about her,
Shall wast so much life in the loue of his wife,
He were better be without her.
But hee that marries a Scold, a Scold, &c.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
O scorne vpon scorne, torment vpon torment. Let me rather be buried aliue then beare this. 〈◊〉
Shee gets loose. Slaues, Rascals, get yee all out of my doores. By vertue of my nayles, I cha • g • yee. • e not leaue an Eye 〈◊〉 a No • e amongst yee

sp.speaker: How. Wid. Bull. Anv.
sp.l: O Lord, O Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come bouncing after my boyes.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.l: Oh how am I wrong'd.

div.stage: Ex. Omnes preter Fit. Tri. Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Sure I 〈◊〉 apprehend this 〈◊〉 as • ight as could bee possi • le the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Madame, I see too much of your vexation; and indeed I suffer too much with you. As I am a Gentleman I will giue you right frendly Counc • ll, if you will heare me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir I ha • e per ••• 'd humanity in you and doe loue it in you. But I know not what to doe, nor whom to heare. I am fallen • nto the pit of bondage, and will take any course for my Redemption. Oh Master Bulfinch.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This will make to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Sir I am wrong • b • yond e • pression. This Gentleman is an eye witnes of my suffrings. Pray come in Sir. I will heare your counsell together with this Gentlemans aduise.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madam • , your case is in my apprehension, most d • sperate, yet 〈…〉 comfort in regard you seeke ad • ise and counse • l. Mine is euer ready, and more fortunate oftentimes the 〈◊〉 . For I doe nothing but vpon good reason and de •• beration.

div.trailer: The end of the third Act.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir I bes •• ch your worship, deale not so seuerely with mee.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirah I will teach you how to deale with Dealers, and not with vertuous Gentlewomen; bring Innocency before Iustice; and be able to lay nothing to her charge.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Indeed sir, the Captaine inform'd me of her; and said he would be here ready to accuse her. Good sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most officious Sir. What warrant had you? None. What is the Captaines name? you know not. Where's his lodgeing? you are ignorant. But here was your cunning; it appeares most plainely, that you thinking her to bee one of the trade, thought to make a Prey of her pu • se: which since your affrightment, could not make her open vnto you, you thought to make her Innocency smart for't. I will make your Knauery smart for't directly. Come is the Mittimus ready? gi' mee't—

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Good your worship, hold your hand. For my poore familie sake.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here take him forth, and let the next Constable conuey him to Nowgate.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir 'tis the first time that euer I offended in this kind. I pray your worship be of a better mind towards me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Away I say directly. As I am in my right Mind and Midlesex. I will shew my iustice on thee.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Do's the Knaue laugh? Bring him backe. May a man aske the cause of your Mirth? Vex. Sir I haue laught at the vexation of a thousand in my dayes. I hope I may haue lea • e once in my life to laugh at mine owne.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Oh is it so? Pray hold you merry sir.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Lady, whereas you were brought before me as a Delinquent, I retaine you as my Mistris. I like her beyond measure. A pretty young thing: new brought to a pace! Ah, h • ! Shee has committed a little Countrey folly, as shee priu • tely confesses. Whats that • It may stand in ranke with that they call vertue here; and then shee is content to li • e as priuately as I please. Shee shall vp, I will winter and sommer her before shee shall see a high way of this Towne. Shee's for my turne directly. Mistris Holdup, is your 〈◊〉 say you?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Camitha Holdup sir. A poore Gentlewoman. My father
bore the office of a Commissioner for the peace in the VVest countrey, till Misfortune wr •• gth his estate out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Squ.
Hold.
sp.p: Tis too true sir. He paid so dearely for't at last, that I haue no more, but my bare breeding, and what I beare about me to liue vpon.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Which is enough • enough directly; if you can beare your selfe discreetly, and containe your selfe within those bounds of Fortune, in which Ile plant you. Alas good soule, weepe not; let Money and Authority bee thy comfort. By which tho • shalt fe • le no want, nor feare no danger. But to our busines. I haue already acquainted you with my Neece Constances disease, and that shee is remou'd out of my house for her health. I will lodge you at a trusty Tenants house where she is vnknowen. You shall take her name vpon you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Which is mine owne already.

sp.speaker: S • u.
sp.p: And if you can but a little counterfet her Melancholly, you may freely passe for her; and my accesses to thee, my sweet Girle, shall crowne vs with f • lnes of delight and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, you haue most worthily made me your owne; and all my study shall be to obey you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now had I but • fit attendant for the person of my loue▪

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Some simple honest body sir.

sp.speaker: • qu.
sp.p: Then we were fitted. How now.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: My Lady Lucklesse man desire to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Stand you by vnseene a while. Send him in. I doe expect some Message now, in the behalfe of her vnlucky Ladyships wise brother, Master Widgi • e, tou • hing my Neece. Now stend how do's my good Lady?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I left her very ill sir; for she has beaten me, and thrust me out of doores with her owne hands, without penny in my purse, or other Cloake o'my back, then the bare Liuory, that a cast Se • uing man can not shake off, of Kna • e and Beggar.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou leftest her very ill indeed. But well, thou wouldst haue me bee a meanes to reestablish thee in thy Lady.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In her seruice sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I speake by a figure Humfrey: for to be inward with, or indeed within a Mistris, is to be a ser ••• e in the most Courtly phrase.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I sir. Those are conuenient S • uants sir. Wee are couenant seruants. They are respected aboue husbands: Wee abased beneath slaues. They purchase place, honors, and offices oftentimes with their Ladies 〈…〉 , when wee finde not our wages without hard words, and are in feare, (poore •• akes) to haue our sloughes pulled ouer our ear • s before the yeare goe about. Wee drudge for our Ladies, they play with their Ladies: But the best is, wee labour and sweat it out for our Ladies, when they are faine to tal • e Physick, and lye in for their Ladies.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most intelligent Humfrey. Let vs retire to the purpose. Put • ase I haue a Mistris in store for you; to whom I may comm • nd you vpon my owne credit, and vndertake for your entertainment and meanes by my owne purse. What would you say? what would you doe?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, I will say ouer the Gent. vshers Grammar to you, and doe her seruice by the rules.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said directly. Incipe Humfride. Say your part.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In a Gentleman Vsher there be eight parts. Boldnesse, Neatnesse, • attery and Secresie, rewarded. Diligence, Obedience Tru • h and Hon • sty, vnrewarded.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What is his B • ldnesse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: His Boldness • is the vse of his Manhood in right of his Ladi • s honour, degree, place or priuiledge, at home, abr • ad, in priuate or publique meeting, for the hand, for the w • ll, for the what she will, • or the what she calls.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How is it rewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: By obtainin • of Sutes made out of cast Gownes or P ••• icoates. Which if 〈◊〉 be a Taylor, as most of our middle sort of Professours are, hee is thereby made a Man in spight of the prouerbe, and th • ust into the high way of aduancement.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Perge Humfrey His neatnesse now?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p:
His neatnesse consists most diue • sly▪ sir. Not on • ly in the decent wearing of those cloathes and c • eane linnen, pruning his hair • , rufsling his Boo • es, or ordring his shooe • tyes; these are poore expressions, a • ourney man Barbar will doo't. But to
doe his office neatly, his g • rb • , his pace, his postures, his co • es on and his comes off, complement • , his visites 〈◊〉
▪

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: His Howdees.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In which a profound iudgement • ould be pussell • d.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I beleeue thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: And the most absolute or artificiall memory set o'the rack. To be able to relate how this Ladies tooth does; and tother La • ies toe. How this Ladies Milk does: and how • others Doctor lik'd her last water: how this Ladies husban • ; and how tother Ladies dogge slept last night: how this childe, that Monk • y, this Nurse, that Parrat, and a • thousand such. Then his neatnesse in Chamber-wo • ke, or about the person of his Lady, in case her Mayd or her Woman be otherwise occupied, to conuey a pin into her r • ffe neatly, or adde a help to her head dressing, as well as Iohn among the Maydes, Lastly, his dexterity in Caruing, and his discretion in Marshalling of meates; to giue eu • ry messe the due seruice, and euery dish his lawfull preheminence.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And how is this neatnesse rewarded Humfrey?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Doubly sir: at boord and at bed▪ by good bits, and the loue of the Chambermayd.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well Humfrey, because wee will not make this scene too long, we will omit the rest: onely why are your last foure parts, Diligence, Obedience, Truth and Honesty vnrewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir. They are parts that spring out of vertue, and are therefore borne with their reward in their mouthes, and ought to expect no further from any seruice in these times.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most edifying Humfrey. I haue a Mistris in store for thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I long to see her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Didst thou never see my Neece Constance?

sp.speaker: How.
Squ.
sp.p:
Feare it not Hum • rey. My 〈◊〉 ease thy care. Neece come forth. [Enter Holdup.] I shall fit you with a seruant. Fall to your Postures Humfrey. Your C • rbe. [He does his postures] So. Your Pace. So. Your Congie. So. Hand your Lady. Good. Arme your Lady. Good still. Side your Lady. Very good. Draw out your Lady. Excellent. Present
your Lady. Singular well, good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p:
Sir, I can Shoulder my Lady too: but that is when 〈◊〉
takes Co • ch; and Foot my Lady, when she alights.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Precious Humfrey, I admire thy Art.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I learnt all of a good old Ladies man in the Strand sir, that must be namelesse.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Humfrey, Walke your Lady to the Burse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O most Hostlerly spoken! Vnder correction sir, Wayt your Lady I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said Humfrey. Here's something for my instruction. Now wayt your Lady to the Burse. She has some tri • les to buy there. I will finde you there presently, and conduct you to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: What shall I doe with all this sir? I would indeed but buy an ounce or two of threed; some Netting pins and Needles, an • a Frame to flourish my worke on. Hereafter I will worke in gold and siluer, if you please, for your owne wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: As I would wish! her simplicity takes mee aboue her beauty. Goe I say. I'le follow. Mee thinkes I eene feele my selfe, thanke my selfe for being in this good humour. What I haue is mine owne, and I will be merry with it directly. —

div.head: Act. IIII. Sce. II.
div.stage: Enter Fitchow, Tridewell, Bulfi • ch, Widgine, A ••• le.

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you now know the calamity I suffer vnder. And you haue sh • w'd mee the best way to comfort: for which I thanke you. I haue giuen you my resolution for a Divo • ce, vpon condition. Before which, I must promise you nothing sir. But I assure you in the meane time, you stand prime in my affection: for I haue in all found you a right worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madame, I haue not vtterance to declare my acceptance of your loue. It must therefore be lock'd vp in my breast, the treasure of my heart. Now for the condition vpon which your Divorce depends, we must see that perform'd, and then—

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Sir, I will make good more then I now may promise.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You speake nobly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It relishe • a little • do much of womanly •• lfulnesse I confesse. But all my wilfulnesse (that I'le promise you sir) shall die in the end of this businesse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well then, before your discreet neighbour M. Bulfi • ch here. If you haue not your will in this, I will disclaime in your favour hereafter. Sir, the condition is (as you may remember—

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend it Sir. That sir Paul Squelch his Neece be first married or contracted, and then she consents to a divorce: And that you be assistant to her brother here to obtaine her for him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: To which I promise my ready helpe, onely I must not appeare in the businesse.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
I will onely appeare in it, for I will not be seene in the
• atter.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As thus sir. I will keepe your counsell: not onely in holding my peace to all the vvorld, but in saying nothing to sir Paul himselfe. Dee apprehend me sir?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And thanke you sir. Now every man to his part M. Widgine, You haue both your sisters and my best directions already, which I doubt not but with the helpe of your Governor you will make good vse of. Madame will you in, and but wish well to our proceedings, and trouble your thoughts no further.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, what helpe he has of me, is for the Ladies and his owne sake, not your's dee heare.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No blustring now good Governour: Prithee restraine thy fury. Thou canst never heare nor speak to that Gent. with any patience; and yet he is on our side now. Prithee let's loose no time. I never • ong'd more for my mothers comming from a Christning, then to be at this Northern Lasse.—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Wanton, you haue begun propitiously: Proceede but confidently, and I'le warrant thee a wealthy husband by it, or a composition that may proue the better purchase.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir, be you and thi • Lady but as confident of my fidelity,
and trust me in this action, and if I breake not the toyles your Kinsm • n is in, and make you Mistris of my Intrest in sir Paul, let all the good you intended me, bee a lockram Co • fe, a blew Gowne, a Wheele and a cleane Whip. You are sure the Lady will yeild to Diuorce, if Constance whom I now perso • ate be first maried or contracted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
Hel.
sp.p: And you are sure that Constance is safe from her discouery.

sp.speaker: Tr • .
sp.p: I vpon the hazard of my discretion.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: To any then that knowes her not very well, If I appeare not the same Constance—you haue giuen me her Character right?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: The best that we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, I haue a fu • ther helpe then, you both imagine yet.

sp.speaker: Tri. Tra.
sp.p: May wee know it.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
It shall be no secret. My Seruant Howdee, whom you and sir Paul, suppose his Lady turn'd away, was by her Ladiship taught onely to faigne it; and cunningly instructed to worke himselfe into the se • uice of Constance, to further her brothers proceedings. And since fortune has put him vpon me, whom hee takes to bee the same Mistris, if I make not
• pt vse of it—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Tis most fairely omenous. Come Lady. Hee cannot. but bee at hand; and our stay may doe hurt, (You remember the Doctors lodging I told you of, and sir Phillips appointment to m • et you there an houre hence?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: All sir. I would vse no other. She is there already. Ex.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No more then; away. Fare you well sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
If my deceit now, should bee disco • ered, before my worke be ended, my Brain tricks might perhaps, in stead of all these faire hopes, Purchase me the Lash. fore Ve • us. my flesh
〈◊〉 trembles to thinke on't. It brings likewise into my consideration, the basenesse of my condition; how much vnpittied the punishment of a Whore is, an • how sodainely it ouertakes her? My ioynt Con • piratours are in no danger. I only run the
hazard, though they are as deepe in fact as my s • lfe. Well. If I scape this pull, and draw any fortune by't, ile change my function sure. A common Whore? Ile be a Nun rather. They come most fitly, and I must into my fit—Withdrawes behind the • anging.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Indeed sir, it was my Ladies plot, but you must take no notice of it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile thanke her with all my heart, and shee shall neuer know on't.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But if sir Paul, my now Master should discouer my deceit, how shall I scape his vengeance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What dost thou thinke of me, weake fellow? Am not I a Commander, ha?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I, in the warre Captaine: but hee is a Iustice of Peace, and a Commander of Captaines in Midlesex, sends two or three drunken Ones to Newgate at a clap sometimes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Feare no discouery Humfrey. Let me but see her, and Ile warrant thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee'll see none but sir Phillip, you must be no body else. Remember that: you must know no other name you haue. Now if you can sir Phillip it handsomely there's it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant thee, and my Gouernour shall sir Phillip me at euery word; and if I doe • ot sir Phillip her, better then euer shee was Phillips in her life, then say I am no Legitimate Widgine.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: • is pa •• your •• rength or reach either by forty I beleeue. I doubt your midle finger is too short Master Widgin • .

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Well, I must venter it. Here shee comes. Has a Baby.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's shee doing. Ods me • making a Baby I thinke Are you good at that ifaith? Ile be at that sport with you, it shall cost me a fall else.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Oh shee has a hundred such • pish toyes. E • ne now shee was great with Child for • ooth as shee could goe. And was perswaded she had a Child as big as I in her belly. I wondred at it, and shee told me shee had had a hundred there as big in her dayes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I but shee knew not what shee said. By and by, I must be a Man-Midwife forsooth and deliuer her: for twas past all Womans skill? Now shee thinkes shee is brought a bed, and nurses the Child her selfe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And who's the father?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O none but sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: • le father it as well as hee. I • t a Boy or a Girle trow▪ Would shee would make a Christning Banquet while wee are here. Harke shee sings.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Peace wayward Barne; O cease thy mo • e:
Thy farre more wayward Daddy's gone:
And neuer will recalled be
By cryes of either thee, or 〈◊〉 :
For should wee cry,
vntill wee dye,
VVee could not sc • nt his cr • elty.
Ballow, Ballow, &c.
H • e ne • ds might in himselfe forese • ,

VVhat 〈◊〉
•• ccessiuely might'st be;
And • ould hee then, (though me foregoe)
His Infant leaue, ere hee d • d know,
How like the Dad
would bee the Lad,
In time, to make fon • Maydens glad •
Ballow, ballew, &c.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is this pretty Mrs. Con •• ance, that you complaine of your Loue before he be lost?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Who be you I pray?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray thee tell her Gouernour. I ha'not the heart to lye now.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p:
It is sir Phillip Lady, come to doe you right. De •
heare?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Yes sir, I heare you vary weell; and could • ene wish
〈◊〉 my heart I could beleeue you.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Speake your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p:
You may Mistris Constance; for as I am an honest man,
I neuer meant to wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I doe bele • ue you sir. But pray prote •• no more by that name till you make your selfe such by marying me. You haue getten a barne by me, I is sure o'that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I come for the same purpose Sweet-heart. Ile both father and keepe thy Child, and make thee an honest Woman. Giue mee your hand before this Gentleman, and your Seruant here; and say but the word; • le get a Licence presently, fetch you away, and dispatch you to night.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Marry mee, marry me, quoth the bo •• y Lasse: and when will you beginne.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
As for thy w • dding Lasse wee' •• doe well enough, in spight
• ' the best o' thy Kinne.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I can but thanke you, obey you, and pray for you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gouernour; wilt thou beleeue me? It ee • e pitties my heart, to wrong so sweet a peece of simplicity. But Fortune has drest her for me to seed on; and Ile fall to.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Or the Deuill to choake you. Well boystrous Master Tridewell, your Ropes end hath driuen me into a busines, here, deserues a whole Rope. But I hope that Dostiny attends not me, though this Mariage be his: And since it is his Fate, faire befall it him, I am discharg'd

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Come Gouernour, we are agreed • lets goe that wee may hye vs againe, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay sir. You shall not say, you married me for nought: you shall heare me sing before you goe.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: What an Owsell tis • shee meanes hee shall marry her for a Song. B • rlady a competent Moderne portion.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: As I was gathring Aprill's flowers,
Which dra • e me to an arbour.
Twere better I my Lap had fill'd.
Although the wet my clothes had spill'd,
Then to ha'found that harbour
For there a subtile Serpent was,
Close lying, lurking in the Grasse.
And there while harmelesse thinking I,
Still watching when the 〈◊〉 would dye,
Lay listning to a Bird,
That singing • ate vpon the Bo • er,
Her noates vnto the falling showre,
the Snake beneath me stird;
And with his sting gaue me a clap,
that swole my belly not my lap.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my troth tis pretty.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
And by my conscience tis true, twere made 〈◊〉
Durham, on a Lasse of my bignesse.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: And in thy clothes I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: But will you be gan now, than all my ioy leaues me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sweet soule, thou shalt haue thy ioy againe. I will ioy thee, enioy thee, and ouer ioy thee. Gouernour let vs fly about this busines. I will not sleepe, before I haue got a License, stolne her away, wedded her, bedded her, and put her in her wits againe.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Are you able to doe that thinke you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Ile warrant thee: for all Maids are mad till they be •
maried.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p:
What say you to that Lady. P • x on you, I run •
sweet hazard to aduance your fortune, doe I not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Remember your Couenant with Master Tridewell Captaine. And when the worke is done, here's my hand, you shall partake of what I get by't. And harke you.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Shee may perhaps, when shee comes to her selfe, and finds me to be no sir Phillip, be a litle startled. But I meane the f •• st night to put so much of my owne loue into her, as shall worke out his I doubt not, or any his that came there before mee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O Gentlemen! my Masters comming, alls spoild if hee take you. Part quickly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Is mine Vncle comd? and mun we part than?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Kisse, and part; kisse and part.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Sweet heart, not a word of mee till I come to fetch you off with honour.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: All be • isons bee with you. Indeed you be the goodliest man, that ere made Maiden faine.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Poore heart shee dotes. I doe not know how much I am in debt to my conscience, till I haue made her amends. —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: This may breed good blood. If I come but as well off o' my old Vncle, as ••• like to come on with my young Cose • , here will be a match vnlook'd for; a match vvithout treaty; a m • tch vntalk'd or vnheard of. Hee is comming before I haue shifted my • ace. Mee thinks I heare the rusting of • is bristles hither. • et my lips must stand the assault; pray loue the Porcupine, leaue none of his quills in 'hem.

div.head: Act. IIII. Sce. V.
div.stage: E • ter Sq • elch to Holdup.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Where's my Girle? My hony sweet Girle? Kisse m • e;
〈◊〉
I say directly: I'le s • cure thee. As I am a Man of Authority, and that of Midlesex, I 'le secure thee. Ha my Las •• , these lips haue the true Elixi •
in 'hem indeede, to restore youth and strength; past all Medeas charmes, or vvhat the Poets vvould haue fai • 'd. How now 〈…〉 Loue? I hope my Neeces habit has not wrought her di • ease into thee.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: No: now I see you sir, I am well: perfectly well: yet pardon me sir. Your absence cannot but breed me feare, when I haue leasure to thinke on my vnworthy condition, and the danger I vndergoe in't.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: 'Twas a thousand pitties that this Wench was seduc'd. Shee might haue ma • e a Wi • e for a good Esquire. Shee would serue a Tradesman yet, most vnblemishably. And vvhen I haue done vvith her, doing that f • r her, as I meane to doe. She may perhaps match with a younger brother, purchase him a place, aduance his fortune, to bee able in the end to repay h • r vvith a Ladiship. 'Tis not vvithout a president; and I will help her to follow the example directly. For vvhat I haue is mine owne, and I vvill be merry vvith it. Ha my bird, my chick • Kisse me. Kisse me vp. So. Kisse me vp I say. So againe. Thou hast don't directly. Maintaine it now, vvith a cordiall • isse. So, so, so▪ Good. Very good; and while it is so, a vvord with you in priuate. Come my bird, mh mh mh.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sit, there's a vvoman below.—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir, vvhat haue I to doe with any vvoman below: Doe you with your vvoman below, I am very well here.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Is the olde man mad trow. Sir, shee will haue to doe with you aboue, if you speak not with her below. I had much a doe to keepe her downe stayres, her case is so lamentable she sayes. I neuer saw a vvoman so importunate in my life sir. You must downe sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am downe already. All's naught. What limb of the devill is' • ? Do'st thou know her?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee sayes shee is vvife to a Constable s • r, that you lately committed; and if your Wor. dos not release him presently, that hee's vndone, and shee's vndone, all their children ar • vndone, that vnborne in her belly is vndone, and I know not how many more are vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hell take her. How could she know that I was here?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Shee spied you in the Streete sir, and followed you, and follow you shee vvould, had you gone into the Priuy Chamber she sweares; her cause enforces her she sayes. And shee is so great with childe too, that no man dares giue her a thrust to keepe her back. I heare her blow vp stayres.

sp.speaker: S • n.
sp.p: Keepe her downe, I'le follow thee—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Good sir be pittifull for the vvomans sake, and release him. Perhaps her reckoning is out, and she has no body to call the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I must home to my Clearke then: for I cannot write here; nor do any good besides I am so vex'd. But I will returne to th • e in the evening, Duck: And since I am so apt to be spied,
• will come disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Indeed I'le put out the Candle when you are here then, for I shall never endure to • ee other shape of Man. O these trunke ho •• are a comely wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be • i • guis'd directly. I will runne through all the shapes of Iupi • er, befor • I will againe be prevented. Farewell. O my • weet! At seuen in the eu • ning expect me.—

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Sweet sayst thou? Thou art not I'le sweare. I am glad he was prevented. I should never held out a course with him, that cannot endure a breathing: a Cheese-shop on fire cannot out-stinke him.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Your Vncle's gone Mistris, and sayes hee will be here at seuen a clock ag • ine. But shall I tell you a fiue thing Mistris?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yea marry Humfrey, what may that be and tis not of Sir Phillip

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But it is of him Mistris. Hee sayes hee will bring a Coach for your at sixe a clock to fetch you away: will you goe with him?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: By my saule that will I an't be all the world over.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: How shall you Vncle finde you at 7 then?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Wee'll leaue him at six and seauens. I meane betwixt both. 'Twill be trim trust me. And hear'st thou me Humfrey. Thou must bid Mistris Traynwell
〈◊〉 to me a little before six •
for a very good reason.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hmh —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, it shall hinder nothing. Wee 'le away the faster.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I thinke she be in her wits already. If not, I must humour her, though I bee put to the trouble to shift her away againe. Shee shall marre no sport that's certaine.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Come with me Humfrey, thou shalt goe eene now, and tell her; and I'le be packing vp the while. —

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: This Clinches. I shall winne my Ladies heart for euer. To mannage two such bus • n • sses more, were enough to raise me Agent for a State.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: Act. V. Scene I.
div.stage: Pate in a Doctors habit. Traynwell, Constance.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To discourse a tedious Lecture vnto you, Lady, in speaking philosophically of the disease of Melancholly, were to shew more learning then discretion. There are large volumes of it in Print, to very slender purpose.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I desire rather your discretion, then the glosse of Learning. I am rather govern'd by the wholsome effects of the one, then the smooth directions o • the other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: To the point then Lady. I see no reason why I should vexe and torment this delicate and tender body, with Physick. Her disease is Melancholly; The cause of this disease I haue found apparantly in the two houres probation since you left her with me, to be Loue, which shee hath so greedily taken in, that it hath overwhelm'd her spirits, and turn'd the faculties of all her senses into a rude confusion, sending forth the vse of them extravagantly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I must not onely approue, but applaud your skill. Tis loue indeed, And • am right glad that your opinion iumps with my owne knowledge: for now I doubt not of your speedy addresse to the cure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: 'Tis done in three words. The Party that shee loues, must be the Doctor, the Medicine, and the Cure.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Sir, the Gentl • man is below, he came with me, onely I would not bring him to her fight vvithout your approbation,
• caring it might doe hurt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Pray call him vp, on perill of my judgement. Ex. Tray. G • ue me your hand Mrs. Constance. I haue good newes for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tis a lo • g whayle • ine I hear • ony.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Gentleman, whom you loue best, shall be your bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He is wed already Sir. Another wife would gar him be put downe at gallowes: an • I vvould not • ee sh • e for all the wordly good that ere I • aw with 〈…〉 . And o' my consci • nce I • e be none of his 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She pra • tl • s very prettily me thinks. 〈◊〉 already? Sure Cupid shot you with a f • or • ed arrow out o • his Crosbow. But what will you say Lady, i • by my Ar • I 〈◊〉 this Gent • eman vnmarried againe, and a Suter vnto y • u pr • sen • ly?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Marry▪ shall I tell you what I'le say sir? Th • t d • serues hanging worse then tother • at • er, you would poyson his vvife by your Art, wod yee? and make your gowne th • re the Hangmans
• ee the second time? It lookes as it had beene once his already; and you like such a Doctor I mu •• tell yee, by your leaue. God bl • sse me fro thee. Mrs. Traynwell where are you?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Out of her wits say they? I feare shee is 〈◊〉 then all of vs, that haue to doe with her. Shee knowes my gowne b • tter th • n I doe: for I haue had but two ho • res acquaintance with it. 'Tis • o longer since I hir'd it of the hangmans Mercha • t a Broker. It might ha' beene Lopus gowne for ought I know.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. II.
div.stage: Enter Traynwell and Lucklesse to them.

sp.speaker: Tray.
sp.p: They are falne out I thinke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
O Mrs. Traynwell, for deare Charities • ake ha' me soone •
〈◊〉 this Man: for I'le nere take ony thing at him. Hee talkes of poysoning.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By my faith you wrong me: Nor of any poysoning purpo • e. I was but putting a case of—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray put vp your Pipes sir. I like not your Musicke: troth nor his countenance nather. Sweet Mrs. Traynwell gar me be shut on him. Now all the joyes of Immortality light o' yee sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is that the Gent?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir. Pray obserue. But how fell you out sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I must first • alute him by your favo • r. Sir, all the accumul • tions of honour showre downe vpon you.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: S • r. May you r •• pe the vvhole harvest of your fruitfull wishes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Deare sir, keep • further fro' him.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: But one vvord sweet Lady; and you shall haue the vvhole benefit of h • s presence to your s • lfe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: • e not afraid sweet-heart, he dares not hurt sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: In • roth he breathes to neare him.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p:
〈◊〉 wa • rant y • u. What has hee done to m • ue her thus? I know not what thi •
〈◊〉 Doctor is. But M. Tridewell put me vpon him; and his • pproved honesty has and must kill all m • s • rust in me.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Your C • ach is ready at dore you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ye • my most d • licate Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: As you finde her then after a few vvords away vvith her. I haue 〈◊〉 my part sir. I' le hold the discreet • ouernesse in talke in the nex • roome.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: But one word call yee this?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: I ha' done sweet soule. Lady I haue instructed the gent. shall we l • au • th • m?

sp.speaker: Tr • .
sp.p:
One vvord, by your leaue first M. Doctor, and I'le attend you. Sir not alone my Discretion, but my Reputation lies at stake: and I make no doubt of your noblenesse vpon your Kin • mans word, my Complotter in this busines. Therefore while I hold argument with the Doctor (who shal by no meanes perceiue our deceit) slip you away with her in your Coach, where M. Tridewell▪ hath appointed, till the Eueni • g; and let me alone to scuffle with the old man the while▪ And then I doubt
not all our troblesome labours shall haue a peaceable end. Ile send old Mad-cap to your Lady in a Thunder-clap. But nobl •
sir, your reputation—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My life and honour be her Guard, and your security.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No more sir. Ile lay no coniurations vpon so noble a spirit. Come Master Doctor—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But doe you loue me Constance?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O right weell sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And will you be my Woman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I is sure, ile nener be mine owne els • .

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you will not goe away with m • c now, if I request you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Any whither but to bed before wee be married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What from your Gouernesse, your Vncle, and all the World?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thanke you too sir. And ta' mee but fro' this ill looking Doctor; for I shall be weell with you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, since you trust me so well, wee two will not part till wee are lawfully made one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Heauen blisse the houre you speake in, and all Saints be with • sses.

div.head: Act. V. Sce. III.
div.stage: Enter Squelch, meeting Trainewell, and Pate.

sp.speaker: Squ
sp.p: Where's this Doctor? where's this melancholly Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O me is hee come?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is this her Vncle?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: E • en he sir. Where's my charge; Mistris Constance?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: S • ue yee sir Ile goe find her—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where's my charge? Ile goe find her! What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Shee was here but now sir, while the Musick plaid. And wee withdrew our sclues, thinking she might sleepe sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There went a Coach away as I came in. Whole was it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A C • ach sir? Alas I am affraid; my flesh trembles.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: At what in your great Master the Diuels name? Where's my Ncece?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir here came in one Master Widgine, the Lady Luckt • s brother—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: As acquainted with the Doctor sir—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: VVell, well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And he saw her sir. But seem'd to depart, when wee withdrew our selues to talke about the cure.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very very well. While you were wisely talking about the cure, a Widgine flies away with the Patient. Where's this Doctor? Doctor I say. Doctor! Hee's run away too, my life on't. A meere plot, a Conspiracie; tis so directly, below there. I can not see how it can bee otherwise. Ent. Cleark. Saw you the Doctor? Yes sir, hee went now forth at the water-Gate, and tooke boat in hast.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Exceeding well▪ How came your Discretion acquainted with this Doctor?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir he was reported to me by very good Iudgements, to be a rare Practitioner.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A most rare fellow, and do's admirable tricks, by slight of heeles. But I may perhaps out-run 'hem—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: My purge workes as I wisht. I am amus'd though at the flight of the Doctor. But I haue too many businesses to intertaine new thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: May I belceue it, Good sir? may I be so happy, that my brother has her?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As I haue truth in me, I am most credibly told so. Mary the worst is, her Vncle is so mad at their escape, th • t hee will neuer giue consent to the match, whereby her portion will bee lesse.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hang him Clod. My will shall be a portion su • ficient to my brother, I care not, though hee giue her not a penny, so VVat has the Wench.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Make you noe more doubt of that, then I doe Madame, who haue vpon the report of it already, prepard the Learned of the Ciuill Law, those that you nominated of your good acquaintance, and are forward to doe you the best office,
who haue appointed to meet before the Iu • ge of the Archdeaacous Court p • esent • y, whither I haue promised to bring, and will attend you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But the other side must be summond by processe.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir Phill • p hath wa • ning already M • dame; and without needlesse processe will bee there before you, and wait your co • ming. So that my selfe and his serua • t, who haue neuer beene both absent from one of your companies, since your Mariage, iustly deposi • g you ne • er did the reallest Rite of Mariage, the bed o • lice, Madame; y • u both consenting, and d • siring a Diuorce, It i • inst • ncly g • au •• ed, with • ut any proceedings i • Law. So that all will be euded in three whispers. Ods pitty, looke who here is.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O are you here my Lady Lu kiesse?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Twas time you found me sir; you might ha'mistaken my name else. F • r withi • this heure, • m • ght haue retu •• 'd the ancient title of your friend, and Awdery F • tchow.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Slow wov, where is my N •••• ?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Where are your wits si • ? you come vpon me inde • d •
What Neece? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: My Neece Censtance, that your brother Widgi • e stole from the Doctor, and is stowne away witha • . But hee must not thinke to scape so? I may take him, and his Duck too, in my D • coy, before they be coupled, as sure as your Ladiship or your Fitchow ship, and they thinke your selues.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sure the old Gentleman is fallen mad. What hath happend?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
The plot smels of your Ladiships policy; you • Ladiships Lilly white fist is t • ule in t • e busines. But I will haue a b • utat sisticuffs in Law with your Ladyship: your great acquain •• nce, and alliance in the Whatshical. Court No •• b ••
〈◊〉
• our ••
〈◊〉 there must not cary it, my great Lady. Directly it must not.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Your • re an vnciuill greasie Co • panion, to vpbraid and reuile me thus in my owne house.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O good Madarne, hurt not your selfe with anger better laugh it out.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hee makes me forget my selfe by his example. Sir you are a Commissioner for the Peace I take it. Do's it become a M • n of you • place and grauity, to fly out in these extreames? You spend too much breath in these lowd noates, very hurtfull to the Lungs, If you will fall into a lower Key, and speake peaceably, I will answere you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray you, Forsooth, or sweet Madame, or what you please; Where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Will you beleeue mee sir? you may: For tis Truth, as I haue any; And before this vvorthy Gentleman; I neuer savv your Neece in my life; only I haue heard shee is a pretty Gen
• evvoman: likely to make a good Match, for vvhich I told my brother of her, and vvould haue treated vvith you for her, cou • d I haue spoken vvith you as I vvish'd by tvvo or three Mess • ges. But vvhither my brother has got her, or wh • r hee, or shee is of my ovvne knowledge, I cannot say directly.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Shee mocks me to my face all this while. Well good-Wise, Mi • ris, Madame—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well my Lord Innekee pers second Sonne: Do's your Pro • ender prick you?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Prick Madame: I tell thee thou Thing, made vp of Chippings, brok • n Beare, Candle-ends, and sisting of Sea cole.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O • t you Curry-combe.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Forbeare sweet Lady, let him be mad by himselfe.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be so reueng'd—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: How pray?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Hee had beene better to haue kild a Man, rauish'd •
Virgiue; nay, done the most dangerous contempt that law
••• ld deuise to punish, then if I take him to suffer vnder my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Ile m • ster vp my Constables, and send out a priuy search immedia • ly.—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What thinke you of your Brothers successe, now Madame?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Much the better, that it vexes him so: Sciruy foule unouth'd fellow.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Looke you now Madame. See who here come • .

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister fall downe, and adore me for my great at chieuement. H • msrey kneele downe to her that shee may dub thee for thy sernice. Neuer did the best nos'd Dogs, that euer were coach'd for their goodnesse, hunt more truely, take more brauely, and cary away more cleanely, then we haue done this dainty peece of flesh here. Sister kisse her, and be better acquainted: shee is mine owne flesh, Ile vphold it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Shee is a Holdup her selfe, if I mistake not her name.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Being your flesh brother, her nearest affinity of blood runs in my veines. Therefore with a sisters loue I embrace you, and bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Mine Vncle will by right wood I feare me. But Ile neare greet for that sir, while I haue your loue.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I know it is shee by her tongue, though I neuer heard her before. Nor euer feare sweet sister, wee shall be all frends shortly.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: I would be glad and twere so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister come hether. Now heare and admire my wit; as well as my Fortune. Humfrey come and take thy share of my sisters wonder.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I hope I perform'd my duty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which wee must not see vnrewarded sister.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No: I meane to giue him my Maid, and a hundred Marks with her, besides all shee has about her.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I am made for euer. I thanke your languishing Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well said Howdee: for my Ladiship is eene at the last gaspe. I am to bee Diuorc'd within this halfe houre. But your proceedings brother? How did shee receiue you at first?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O at first, shee was the prettiliest mad that ere you saw. You your selfe can not deuise to be so mad, as shee was.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
And all for sir Phillip, shee would loue none but sir Phillip, speake to none but sir Phillip. I told her I was sir Phillip,
(ah God a mercy Humfrey: that was thy inuention.) Then the litle Vip • r hang vpon me, not to be shak'd off, til I promis'd her Mariage, and to father a Child, which, in her distraction, shee conceited shee had by me. I promis'd her any thing; so tooke her into an inner too me, to make all sure, as well within as without; and I so phillipt her—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough brother, no more. I vnderstand you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
But I must haue more, and shall neuer haue enough on't. It passeth your vnderstanding and mine too, the delight of it. [Sing] Oh what a delight shee gaue me. And how light I am after
〈◊〉
Heigh. My pretty sweet Rascall.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough I say.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You doe not loue to heare on't, because you lack it. But you shall heare the Miracle it wrought sister. The losse of her Mayden head recouerd her wits. I made her right and streight in an instant. And now shee loues me in my owne person; knowes me for a Widgine, and will not giue her Wat for the best sir Philip of them all. And longs for nothing but the Priest and Bed time. Ha my sweeter and sweeter I My Gouernour's gone sor a Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: So, ha you done now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ile vndertake—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Yet againe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That Humfrey, and I with the tricks and trinkets, wee haue about vs will cure all the mad Maids of her standing in the Tovvne. And doe not thinke, but much may be gotten to professe it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You haue made a large relation Master Widgine, and a pleasant, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh I could liue and dye in this discourse sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady doe you thinke of the time?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I will instantly along vvith you. Hewdee come you vvith me. Brother, the search hath past this house already. You any goe in vvith your Svveet-heart, and stay here safely. Goe in, and keepe close, till I send to meet me at Supper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In and in sister, and be close enough, seare not—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Now sir when you please.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am your seruent Lady—

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistri • , I will goe no further in this businesse, then you haue lim •• ed me in your directions: 'twill be revenge enough for my disgrace to make him see his error.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Therefore be discreet and secret. The disguise hee is in I haue told you. The place is this. At the dore you shall leaue me. The houre 7 a clock.

sp.speaker: Vex.
