sp.p: Mistris, I will not watch more truly at Midnight, then I will pray for you for this Lisc • uery. I will instantly call my priuy-search, guard, and catch a bird, of Iustice in the lime-twigs of his owne Warrant.—

div.head: Act. V. Scene IX.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: I tit not speak with Sir Paule then, it seemes, to know the reason vvhy I am subdoodled thus, In I protest and vow a kind of • ooles Paradise.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Good sir beare your iniury with a Mans patience. Sir Paule will not be long absent. And till hee comes, my Mistris entreates you (for your owne good) to take his part vpon you, in giving entertainment to divers of his friends, who are invited hither to a Feast to night.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: H • you any Whitpots?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Much better meat sir. But here's the strangenesse of it; and the onely occasi • n that r • quires you ayde in the entertainment. This great Supper or •• ast (as I may properly call it) was appointed by Sir Poule himselfe, the money to buy the Provision • d live • 'd by his owne hand, to his own Servant; the Guests of h • s owne election; vet he, out of the multiplicity of crosse effaires, that haue happ'ned this day, hath quite forgot that there was any such preparation, or any such m • eting inten • ed, as appeares evidently by his absence. But • y Mistris has got all the meate privately made ready at the next house, on purpose that h • sh u • d see nothing—

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: To try is he would forget it or no?

sp.speaker: B • a.
sp.p: Right sir. I haue bidden all the Guests: and expect them immediatly.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But what must I say to 'hem?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Onely sal • te 'hem, bid 'hem welcome; Tell'hem Sir Paule was hastily call'd forth on his Majesties affaites; Entreat their patience till his returne, vvhich you know will be every sodaine although you know not vvhere he is; and so forth, as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Your Master abroad and not within say you?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Yes. But good sir stay his comming, I pray you, for his good.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
I partly apprehend you at full. Mistris Traynwell appointed me to come too with all possible speede. M. Vonsens •
you are well apprehended.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Onely salute 'hem, bid' hem welcome. Tell'hem Sir Paule was hast • ly call'd forth on his Maiesties affaires. Entreat their patience till his returne, which you know vvill bee very sodaine, although you know not vvhere he is. And so forth as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Loue has made you a Courtier. M Nonsense

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No I protest and vow. I doe but speake as they say.—

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What haue you said Sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: What you said I haue an ill verbatim else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I said but the meaning of what you should say, and put it in your owne vvords.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No sir. I will take your owne vvords for this matter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I am beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: I am glad Fortune has sent one man of Civill government before the Roarers come. Here comes some of 'hem already. I'le downe and looke to the rest of the house.

div.stage: Enter Lucklesse, Constance, disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Saue you sir. Are you the Worshipfull of the house?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you sir.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir?—

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Mistake me not I beseech you, I apprehend you to be some great stranger here: because you know the place better then the Master of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You doe not mock me sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, This is one of the Guests?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Onely salute 'hem. Bid 'hem vvelcome—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Tell 'hem Sir Paule vvas hastily call'd forth on his Maiesties affaires—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is this a Parrat or a Popingay?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Entreat their patience till his return, which you know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Doe you know vvhat you say sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Will be very sodaine, although you know not where hee is—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I did I vvould not seeke him here sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: And so forth as occasion serues.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is some inchaun • ed P • ace, and the people are charm'd. I haue mistaken the house sure.

div.stage: Enter Tridewell and Fitch • w disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Where's this hospitable Knight that invites Strangers. I meane meere Strangers, that hee knowes not. Shew me the Lad of bounty. I hunger not for his Sapper as I doe to salute him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hee vvill proue the greatest stranger here himselfe I thinke, for he is not at home sir. I am a Guest as you are, and vvould be as glad to see him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He dos not meane to ieare vs dos he?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I bese • ch you mistake not so his purpose sir: which is faire vvelcome, and good cheare to you all. Therefore Gentlemen and ladies, vvill it please you to entertaine one another a while. [Enter Cleark vvith Sack and I'obacco.] Look yee. Here's good Sack, and good I'obacco. And before the rest of the Guests b • co • e, Sir Paule vvill be here himselfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellow speakes.

div.stage: Enter Anv. widg. Holdup. and Howdoe disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As I am a Iustice of Peace I cannot apprekend, and yet me thinks I doe. What sort of people these Gentlemen may be. See: more I Is sir Paule turn'd swaggerer? Or is his house abus'd by servants? I vvill not leaue it, vntill they goe out before mee like a layle deliuery. They lo • ke like men betwixt a Repriue and Pardon. Friend: Are these sir Paules elected friends?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: His protected friends sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Protected?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
I sir. There is a fraternity of them. The brothers of
the Protect. There's not a man of 'hem, but has all Mayors, Sheriffes, Bayliffes, Sergeants at Mace, Marshalls men, Constables, and other his Maiesties Officers, in a Combcase in his pocket. They are a Generation that never eate but in Parliament time, and now every table is full of them.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I should wonder what they did here else. See. A roaring Doctor too, broke out o' the Kings Bench.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By your leaue Gallants. I perceiue your Company is not yet full.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Are you of the invited sir?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: It is not to be doubted sir. Yet a Voluntary. But there are some without that are more then invited, yet come against their wills.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How meane you M. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Brought sir by a Constable and Officers, to be examin'd. Where's the iolly Iustice?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What are they can yee tell sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, and a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A Spaniard, Ha!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I, a Spaniard, Ha: if you will haue it so:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If we had but a Iustice among vs to Examine 'hem, it might passe the time well till sir Paule came.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Iustice, and for the same purpose too for ought we know, that shall not resuse to doe it, and in sir Paules Gowne and Cap too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a witty fellow.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, you cannot doe a more acceptable office for your friend, then to execute his place in his absence. Your anthority makes you capable of it; and I doe the rather perswade it, because the Gentlemen whom you wisely suspect for loose person • , may see some example of Iustice; which may preuent some present euill in their stay here.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you friend. Giue mee the Gowne and Chayre, and let the Delinquents approach. Vmh, vmh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Tis a Spaniard indeede.

div.stage: Enter Vexhem, Squelch, like a Spaniard, Trayn. Cleark.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p:
An English Spaniard sir, And therefore the verier
knaue: as will bee prou'd I doubt not, to his shame, and my renowne in the Common 〈◊〉 . By your Worships leaue.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What newes b • ing • ou M. Constable?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Spanish newes sir. Wi • t please your Worship to examine the vertue of my Warrant, and then these Persons aecordingly?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very good! I am brought before my selfe to bee examin'd, and before a fine rable too! how the deuill brok this vnknowne N • tion into my house, or doe not I mistake it? My foolery has led me into a fine predicament. I will not yet disclose my selfe: but looke a little surther towards the event.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Are you a Spa • iard sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Such a one as you see Signior.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: See Signior. Hee speakes nothing but Spanish. The question will be how we shall vnderstand this Examinant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
I do see Signior I thanke the light, that you are a goodly man of outward parts, and ezcept it were the black Knight himselfe, or him with the Fistula, the proprest man I haue seene of your Nation. They are a People of very spare dyet, I haue
• eard, and therefore seldome fat. Su • e you you haue had most of your br • eding in this C • untrey, the dyet whereof you like better then your own, which makes you linger here, after all you Country men, vpon • ome vn • ouch plot. And I shall wonder therefore how you can speake no English. Can you speake no English at all sir? Answere me I pray.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not an English word not I s •• . Alasse I haue not been siue • ayes in the K • ngio • e.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is exc • llent!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I, peace Y u'll marre all if you laugh.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 , what shall wee doe then? Gentlemen, haue any of you any Spanish, to helpe mee to vnderstand this strange S • a • get?

sp.speaker: T • i.
sp.p: Not a Riall sir not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor a Rialls worth amongst vs of any language but sh • er • English.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What S • iere of our Nation is next to Spaine? Perhaps he may vnd • rst • nd that Shi • r, English.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Deuonshire or Corn • all sir.

sp.speaker: N • n.
sp.p: Neuer credit me, but I will spowt some Cornish at him. Peden bras vidne whee his cregas.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Am I transform' • vtterly? Is my Language alter'd with my apparell, or are you all mad? what vnspeakeable misery is this.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I see we shall neuer vnderstand, nor doe good on him, till hee be instructed in the English tongue.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: And please your worship, the best Vniuersity for this purpose will be Bridewell. I am acquainted with the best Tutors there, Master Cleanewhip, Master Dri • lash, and diuers others.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You o • licious Rascall, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: No such matter sir. But in my right mind, and Midlesex feare it not.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: It must be so. His instruction will cost litle there, if hee be not too old to learne. Therefore set him by, and let mee fall vpon the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Oh, hee's rarely vext.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Now Gentlewoman, will it please you to be vnmasqu'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir looke you, I dare shew my face.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Mistris Trainowell, as I apprehend.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mistris Trainewell.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Trainewell!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Euen shee Gentlemen, as I will more circumstantially reueale vnto you presently, after a word or two with my fellow prisoner, for which I craue your fauour.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: With all my heart, so you can speake Spanish and make him vnderstand you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You see I am not the Woman you tooke me for: but one ordain'd for your greater good. If you will giue me my present demand. I will turne all your disgrace into laughter; make you of worthier esteeme now at the instant, then euer you were, by the generall approbation of these, and all that know you beside. Your Neece to shall be restor'd to your owne liking, and all shall be as well as you can wish. Otherwise, if you haue a mind to bee euerlastingly sham'd, by being perpetually laught at, take your owne course, Ile take mine.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am astonish'd. What is your Demaund?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Whereas your purpose was to make a Whore. Make me your honest Wife; no more. Bee sodaine in your resolue, all will be naught else.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I am in a mischieuous streight then. Redime to captum. Thy wit deserues my loue. Ile do't; here's my hand and faith, Ile
do't. Tho • art mine, and I am thine directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Then • earke you sir.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Sir what will you say, if this Gentlewoman conuert the Spaniard, turne him true English subiect, and present him to you with the oaths of Alegiance, & S • premacie in his mouth presently?

sp.speaker: Bull
sp.p: I wil say, she • e • erues • or euer hereafter to hold her peace.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Now bear • vp sir. Looke confidently, and say, you put on your Disguise purp • sely to intertaine disguis'd Guests. Come auant with your Picca de goat, and beginne with the Iustice here.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou hast made me a M • n for euer, and I will make thee a Woman directly. Gallants saue you. See here the Metamor. phosis, that meanes to metamorphose you all. Alas I know you for all your Disguises, and thought to intertaine you in your k • nd.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Sir P • ul Squelch!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I •• st out of you, my Vsurper, and most Vpstartical Iustice, whose o • lice is your trade, and Clearke your Prentice, I will draw a man of litle, or no Moment: yet my frend, and Master Bulfinch, out of the Chaire of Iustice. • his my prognosticate the p • t • ing of my selfe, or many others out of Commission within these few yeares; though I am no Prophet. Doe I speake English now? Doe I know you now, or you me?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Question 〈◊〉 , we should know one another sir Paul: or else o • e of vs two were both very ignorant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: To proceed in my Metamorphosis. I will change you most confus'd Roarer, into an accomplisht Knight. And bid you welcome, noble sir Phillip Lucklesse.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I like the change well, and thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Next sir of you Roarer, or Iieter, or whatsoeuer you are, I will make a compleat Gentleman, most answerable to you name Master Tridewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: But out of you Master Doctor, I will pick a certaine Knane. W • ere is my Neece slrah?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Which of your N • eces sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Haue I so many sir? I meane my only one Constance, find her me, • r I will translate you out of an Aesculapian Cocke into a Newg •• e
• ird immediatly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir if you will Metamorphose me out of a Batch • lor, into a Bridegroome, Ile shew you your Neece.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: This my Neece?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: O haue I found you Mistris? Sir this is the Gentlewoman I brought before your worship to day.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold they peace; art in thy right mind?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: As I am in my right mind and Midlesex, it is she sir. I had not matter enough then to lay to her charge; for which I thanke your worship I kist Newgate. But now I haue sir; she has lest a Child vpon our Parish, I am sure got by an vnknowne father; and has beene a loose Liuen, both at Duke Humfreyes, and most of the winkd it houses about the Towne these foure yeares: which I can sufficiently proue.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Knaue. Ile put these plums i' thy mouth else

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, my Child shall trouble your Parish no longer, here is a Father, my troth plight Husband, sufficient to keepe it and me, wilt thou not Duck?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Duck? my name is Widgi • e, you mistake the man sure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sure I doe not. This Gentleman, and this Gentlewoman, and this trusty Seruant of ours are my witnesses, I am your Wife sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I am vn • one, quite cast away. Sister helpe mee now with your Law wit, or I perish for euer.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This is not to bee endured: cheating, and vile abuse, This contract can not bee lawfull. One person mistaken for another a lawfull impediment to be diuore'd for, though they were married.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I • might doe well if (as hee con • esses himselfe) he had not made all too sure, as well within as with • ut.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir Phillip, while they wrangle out their cause, l • t vs agree: Find you but the meanes to make her lawfully your Wife, and here take her with my faithfull promise, of the equall halfe of any estate presently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
I say this is no lawfull contract: And though we are legally diuorc'd, yet neither he nor I may lawfully marry, while w •
both liue, hauing beene lawfully married. And till you can disproue that, sir Ile forbid your Banes good sir Phillip, and lay your hopes a cooling, frendly Master Tridewell, for your loue in managing this businesse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Lady giue me leaue, if I haue strayn'd a point of friendship, it was your loue gaue the strenght to my wit. Fit.
〈◊〉 loue?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your loue indeed Lady. Which (and which Cupid pardon me for) now, that I see I may enioy, I am not so eagerly taken with, yet if you will—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Sir you cannot enioy me, not he her, lesse you can disproue
the lawfulnesse of our former Mariage.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: To cleare that point, doe you know the Minister?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Tis not so long since, but I can remember his face.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Then to continue sir Pauls Metamorphosis? Ile draw him out of this Doctor. Is not this hee?

sp.speaker: Fit
sp.p: It is. But is not hee a lawfull Minister; I would know that.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To cleare that doubt there lyes my Order of Priesthood.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who, Oliuer!—

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Euen hee, the Parson Nochurch, and this my Patron, whom I must beseech together with the whole company, to preserue me out of the high Commission: for looke you, here is againe your Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Would you doe this Master Tridewell?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Faith I foresaw an vnto wardnesse in the Match: which if you repent the breach of, there's your Licence; and the way to Church lyes before you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No sir. First get my brother free of his contract, and then a Licence with your owne name, and Ile waite on you to Church, as soone as you will.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O that's done already. What are • ou agreed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Most happily sir, sister alls well againe. I haue giuen her a hundred pound to relinquish her right in me. Which afore all these witnesses you doe; doe you not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes most freely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well then, I will not forsweare to marry, But if euer I steale a Wife againe, let her be a witch, and may I ourn with her for company. Gouernour, thou art out of countenance, and thou too honest Humfrey, me thinkes. Come beare vp. I forgiue. Twas your errors, not malice.

sp.speaker: Ho • .
sp.p: Sir for my part, ile take my corporall oath—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It s • ll not need good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And for me sir—wid. Nay, I dare not but beeleeue th • e before thou speakest Couernour: therefore prithee lets not talke o • 't our selues, but quietly, and presently beginne our trauels, that we may heare no body else talke on't.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Gentlemen and L • dies, I
• ee you all at peace • o well, that I wish no further content to any, except Master Nonsense h • re.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: Neuer credit me but I haue had sport en • ugh'o conscience, and if I doe not make a Stage phyen't, when I come into Cornewall: I protest and vow then say there was Nonsense in this.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I am glad you conclude so
• rendly with the rest. All the vnquietnesse will be in the Kitchin presently If your meat stay for you. Gallants. Knock Within I was time to speake. They knock at Dresser already. Will yee in?
sp.l: You • re all Welcome: And I wish euery Guest
as merry, as our Northern • asses Feast.
